next_steps.note: "Brainstorm potential themes or subjects for the poetry (e.g., nature, love, loss, social commentary). Add 3-5 to the 'Ideas' list.",
"Research contemporary poets and poetry styles to identify potential inspiration. Document 2-3 poets/styles in 'Ideas'.",
"Draft a first poem – aim for a short, free-verse piece, focusing on imagery. Add '[Draft 1 - Title]' to 'Progress' once completed.",
"Define a project scope. How many poems will this project encompass? Add this number to 'Ideas'.",
"Create a 'Revision Notes' section within the board to capture feedback and ideas for improvement on draft poems."
"Brainstorm 3 potential themes or subjects for the next set of poems, documenting ideas in the 'Ideas' list.",
"Draft a single poem (any length) focusing on one of the brainstormed themes, adding it to 'Progress' as a first draft.",
"Review the 'Ideas' list and prioritize the top 2 most compelling ideas for further development, noting reasons for prioritization.",
"Identify one potential resource (e.g., poet to read, writing prompt website, anthology) to inspire new work and add it to 'Ideas'.",
"Define the criteria for 'completion' of this poetry project (e.g., number of poems, specific style, submission goal) and document in 'Progress'."
"Choose one of the 'Ideas' (Found Poetry, Poetry Pairing, Micro-Poetry, Poetry Swap, or Prompt Jar) and dedicate 30 minutes to *starting* that exercise today.",
"Create a simple document (text file, note, etc.) titled 'Poetry Ideas - In Progress' to track which exercises are being attempted and any initial thoughts.",
"Review the 14 pending next steps (mentioned in 'Additional Context') and prioritize the top 3 based on feasibility and potential impact.",
"Set a realistic goal for poetry output this week (e.g., complete 3 micro-poems, finish one found poem, or participate in one poetry swap).",
"Brainstorm potential sources for text snippets if opting for the 'Found Poetry' exercise (newspapers, magazines, books, websites)."
```json
"Begin 'Found Poetry' exercise: dedicate 30 minutes to collecting text snippets from at least three different sources (newspapers, books, online articles).",
"Select a piece of visual art or music and begin drafting a poem inspired by it – aim for a first draft within 2 hours.",
"Create a 'Poetry Prompt Jar' by writing down at least 10 prompts on slips of paper. This should take approximately 15 minutes.",
"Identify a writing partner for a 'Poetry Swap' and agree on a timeframe for exchanging first drafts (e.g., within 5 days).",
"Commit to writing three micro-poems (haiku, senryu, or three-line poems) today, focusing on capturing a single image or feeling in each."

ideas.note: "**Experiment with Found Poetry:** Collect snippets of text from various sources (newspapers, books, online articles) and rearrange them to create a poem. This circumvents initial drafting hurdles and encourages unique perspectives.",

"**'Poetry Pairing' Exercise:** Select a painting, photograph, or piece of music and write a poem *inspired* by it. Focus on capturing the mood, texture, or narrative suggested by the external stimulus.",

"**Micro-Poetry Challenge:** Commit to writing a series of very short poems (e.g., haiku, senryu, tanka, or three-line poems) daily for a week. This builds momentum and encourages concise, impactful writing.",
"**'Poetry Swap' with a Friend:** Exchange first drafts with a friend or fellow writer for constructive feedback. Focus feedback requests on specific areas like imagery, rhythm, or clarity.",

"**Develop a 'Poetry Prompt Jar':** Write down a variety of creative writing prompts (single words, phrases, scenarios, or 'what if' questions) on slips of paper and draw one each time you want to start a new poem. This eliminates decision fatigue and introduces unexpected inspiration."
